div1.p: Noguchi suspects a case of yellow fever in Africa was really Weil's disease.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, July 31, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302006]
div1.p:
Thank you for forwarding me a copy of Dr. Connal's letter to Dr. Rose,
relative to a case of suspected yellow fever in an Italian died at Warri on
Nov. 9, 1922. I note with interest what Dr. Young says regarding the differentia-
tion between the histological changes in yellow fever and Weil's disease. He cites
Hoffmann's description of pathological changes of the liver of guinea pigs died
of L. ieteroides infection and of ieterohemorrhagiae (Weil's disease) in support
of his diagnosing this case as probable Weil's disease, but from my comparative
studies of the liver and kidneys of man died of yellow fever on one hand and of
Weil's disease on the other I feel that such differentiation is not always clear
as there exists border-line cases where a severe case of Weil's disease may
produce all the changes which may occur in mild form of yellow fever. Rocha-
Lima's middle-zone necrosis in the yellow fever liver is not specific or even
pathognomonic for yellow fever. This part of histological studies in yellow
fever and allied diseases certainly need revision on a vastly more comprehensive
series of cases than hithertofore done.

It is interesting to note, however, that the changes were not severe
and I regarded them to be a case of severe Weil's disease or else that of mild
form of yellow fever. It may be recalled that Dr. Darling made the diagnosis
of malaria on this same case. A pure histological diagnosis in a case such as
this one is rather indecisive.
